cards.back:
A systematic method to solve PLANAR circuits by:
1. Identifying all meshes (inner loops)
2. Assigning mesh currents (usually clockwise)
3. Writing KVL for each mesh
4. Solving the system of equations

A mesh is a loop that contains NO OTHER LOOPS inside it.

Think of it as the 'windows' when the circuit is drawn flat on paper.

Also called an 'inner loop' or 'independent loop'.

Sum of voltage drops around the mesh = 0

For resistor in one mesh only:
V = i_mesh × R

For resistor shared by meshes:
V = (i_this - i_other) × R

R_kk = Sum of ALL resistances in mesh k

R_kk = Σ Rⱼ for all j in mesh k

(Always positive)

R_kj = NEGATIVE of resistance shared between meshes k and j

R_kj = -R_shared(k,j)

(Always ≤ 0)

Note: R is symmetric, R_kj = R_jk

Use supermesh when a CURRENT SOURCE is SHARED between two meshes.

Supermesh gives:
1. Constraint: i₂ - i₁ = I_source
2. Combined KVL: Go around both meshes, skip the current source

If current source I is in the OUTER branch of mesh k:

i_k = I (directly known!)

No equation needed for this mesh.

Standard mesh equations:

Ri = v

Where:
• R = M × M resistance matrix
• i = mesh current vector
• v = voltage source vector (+ for rise in CW direction)

Solve: i = R⁻¹v

Exclusive branch (in mesh k only):
I_branch = i_k

Shared branch (between k and j):
I_branch = i_k - i_j

Direction follows mesh k's direction.

cards.front: Mesh vs Nodal: When to Use Mesh
cards.back:
Mesh analysis is best when:

✓ Circuit has many voltage sources
✓ Many series elements
✓ Fewer meshes than (N-1) nodes
✓ Need currents directly
✓ Circuit is planar

✗ Don't use if circuit is non-planar!
